ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: To a student with extensive prior knowledge about Eastern Europe, yes. To others, it's less likely to resonate

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: The course allowed for research on a topic of our choosing, so I could investigate a topic of relevance for my dissertation. I appreciated thisflexibility, although it did make peer reviewing essays a bit unwieldy because of the diversity of topics. The research paper was nonetheless a useful exercise for me. I wish, again, that the earlier sessions of the course had been a bit broader; I'm not sure I came away with enough knowledge to, say, take an undergraduate exam on the subject at the end of the semester.

I enjoyed the workshop format and the presentation of our papers, but I wished we had had more direction from Snyder regarding expectations and what it means to give a successful versus empty/boring/unhelpful presentation. He stressed staying within time limits, but other than that, there was little substantive direction.Hisinput in office hours was super helpful in framing my paper, but in class there was little in the way of suggestions, guidelines, etc... As someone who's just learning the discipline of history from a graduate perspective, I wanted a little bit more training.
